definition: A process or set of rules followed in calculations or problem-solving operations, often by a computer.
A software application used to access and navigate the internet.
Networked computer servers where information and software applications are stored and accessed remotely.
An organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.
The method by which information is converted into secret code that hides the information's true meaning.
A network security device that monitors and filters incoming and outgoing network traffic based on an organization's previously established security policies.
A unit of information equal to one billion bytes or 2^30 bytes, depending on context.
The physical components of a computer system.
A global network of interconnected computers that communicate through standardized protocols.
A high-level, class-based, object-oriented programming language designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.
The core of a computer's operating system, with complete control over everything in the system.
An open-source operating system modelled on UNIX.
Software designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to a computer system.
A group of two or more computer systems linked together.
A cross-language, cross-platform application programming interface for rendering 2D and 3D vector graphics.
A set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices.
A request for information from a database.
A device that forwards data packets along networks.
The programs and other operating information used by a computer.
A piece of data that symbolically represents a larger, more complex piece of information.
The address of a World Wide Web page.
Not physically existing as such but made by software to appear to do so.
The complex system of interconnected elements that enables access to the Internet.
A metalanguage which allows users to define their own customized markup languages, especially in order to display documents on the Internet.
A file format used for data compression and archiving.
A natural electrical phenomenon characterized by the appearance of streamers of reddish or greenish light in the sky, usually near the northern or southern magnetic pole.
Perfect happiness; great joy.
A deep gorge, typically one with a river flowing through it.
Tiny drops of water that form on cool surfaces at night, when atmospheric vapor condenses.
A sound or series of sounds caused by the reflection of sound waves from a surface back to the listener.
The plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
A slowly moving mass or river of ice formed by the accumulation and compaction of snow on mountains or near the poles.
The line at which the earth's surface and the sky appear to meet.
Having solidified from lava or magma.
Cheerful and friendly.
A toy consisting of a tube containing mirrors and pieces of colored glass or paper, whose reflections produce changing patterns that are visible through an eyehole when the tube is rotated.
A stretch of salt water separated from the sea by a low sandbank or coral reef.
A piece of grassland, especially one used for hay.
A cloud of gas and dust in outer space, visible in the night sky either as an indistinct bright patch or as a dark silhouette against other luminous matter.
A fertile spot in a desert where water is found.
A large open area of grassland, especially in the Mississippi River valley.
A hard white or colorless mineral consisting of silicon dioxide, found widely in igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks.
A small wave or series of waves on the surface of water, especially as caused by an object dropping into it or a slight breeze.
A grassy plain in tropical and subtropical regions, with few trees.
A vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen.
The fully shaded inner region of a shadow cast by an opaque object, especially the area on the earth or moon experiencing the total phase of an eclipse.
A mass of whirling fluid or air, especially a whirlpool or whirlwind.
The distance between successive crests of a wave, especially points in a sound wave or electromagnetic wave.
The chemical element of atomic number 54, a rare, odorless, noble gas under standard conditions, used in some fluorescent lamps and photographic flash units.
Produce or provide (a natural, agricultural, or industrial product).
The time at which something is most powerful or successful.
